quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 4: Magnetic Force on Current-Carrying Conductors
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: The magnitude of the magnetic force on a straight conductor is given by which formula?
questions.explanation: For a straight wire of length $L$ carrying current $I$ in a magnetic field $B$, the force is $F = ILB\sin\theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle between the current direction and magnetic field.

questions.question: A horizontal wire carries current from left to right. If a magnetic field is applied vertically upward, in which direction will the wire be pushed?
questions.explanation: Using the right-hand rule: thumb points in current direction (right), fingers in field direction (up), palm pushes in force direction (out of the page).

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ m}$ long wire carrying a $5.0\text{ A}$ current is placed in a $0.1\text{ T}$ magnetic field. If the wire is parallel to the field, the force is:
questions.explanation: Force $F = ILB\sin\theta$. When wire is parallel to field, $\theta = 0^\circ$, so $\sin 0^\circ = 0$ and $F = 0$.

questions.question: Two parallel wires carry currents in opposite directions. What is the nature of the force between them?
options: They exert no force on each other.
questions.explanation: Parallel wires with opposite currents generate magnetic fields that interact repulsively. The field around each wire exerts a force pushing the other wire away.

questions.question: The definition of the "Ampere" is based on the force between two parallel wires. What is that force per unit length when $I_1 = I_2 = 1\text{ A}$ and $r = 1\text{ m}$?
questions.explanation: Force per unit length between parallel wires: $\frac{F}{L} = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi r} = \frac{4\pi \times 10^{-7} \times 1 \times 1}{2\pi \times 1} = 2 \times 10^{-7}\text{ N/m}$. This defines the ampere.

questions.question: If you double the current in a wire and triple the length of the wire within a magnetic field, the magnetic force increases by a factor of:
questions.explanation: $F \propto IL$. Doubling current ($2\times$) and tripling length ($3\times$) gives overall factor $2 \times 3 = 6$.

questions.question: A rectangular current loop is placed in a uniform magnetic field. Even if the net force on the loop is zero, it may experience a:
questions.explanation: Forces on opposite sides of the loop are equal and opposite but may not act along the same line, creating a torque that tends to rotate the loop even when net force is zero.

questions.question: In a DC motor, what is the role of the "Split-Ring Commutator"?
options: To increase the magnetic field strength.
To reverse the current direction every half-rotation.
To prevent the wire from melting.
questions.explanation: The commutator reverses the current in the coil each half-rotation, ensuring the magnetic torque always acts in the same direction to maintain continuous rotation.

questions.question: A wire of length $0.5\text{ m}$ experiences a force of $1.2\text{ N}$ when carrying $6\text{ A}$ perpendicular to a field. What is the field strength $B$?
Which of the following describes the "Motor Principle"?
options: A moving magnet creates a current in a wire.
A current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field experiences a force.
A battery provides voltage to a circuit.
questions.explanation: The motor principle states that a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field experiences a mechanical force. This is the fundamental operating principle of electric motors.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered magnetic forces on current-carrying wires, including direction rules, force calculations, and practical applications like motors.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of wire forces and interactions. Review the force between parallel currents and the definition of the ampere.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) The force formula $F = ILB\sin\theta$, 2) Using the right-hand rule for force direction, 3) Force between parallel wires, 4) How motors use magnetic forces.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review the magnetic force on a current-carrying wire formula, practice the right-hand rule, and understand the interaction between parallel currents.
